skill.name: etetoolkit
skill.description: Phylogenetic tree toolkit (ETE). Tree manipulation (Newick/NHX), evolutionary event detection, orthology/paralogy, NCBI taxonomy, visualization (PDF/SVG), for phylogenomics.
skill.summary: Phylogenetic tree toolkit (ETE). Tree manipulation (Newick/NHX), evolutionary event detection, ortho...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: This is a scientific computing skill using the legitimate ete3 Python library for phylogenetic tree analysis. The 442 static findings are overwhelmingly false positives triggered by markdown documentation code blocks (```python, ```bash delimiters flagged as 'Ruby/shell backtick execution'). The actual Python scripts contain only standard file I/O for tree processing. No command execution, credential access, or malicious patterns exist. The critical heuristic about 'Code execution + Network + Credential access' is a false positive triggered by documentation mentioning optional NCBI database download (public data, no credentials required). Safe for publication.

content.user_title: Analyze phylogenetic trees with ETE Toolkit
content.value_statement: Scientists need to manipulate phylogenetic trees, detect evolutionary events, and create publication-quality visualizations. This skill provides a complete Python toolkit for tree analysis with support for Newick formats, NCBI taxonomy integration, and multiple output formats.
actual_capabilities: Load and manipulate phylogenetic trees in Newick, NHX, PhyloXML, and NeXML formats
Detect evolutionary events including duplication and speciation using tree reconciliation
Build species trees and annotate nodes with NCBI taxonomy information
Create publication-quality visualizations in PNG, PDF, and SVG formats
Compare trees using Robinson-Foulds distance and identify topological differences
Analyze hierarchical clustering dendrograms with quality metrics
limitations: Requires ete3 Python package installation for full functionality
NCBI taxonomy database download requires network access on first use (~300MB)
Interactive GUI features require Qt dependencies
Large trees with more than 10,000 leaves may require memory optimization

use_cases.title: Gene family evolution analysis
use_cases.description: Analyze gene trees to detect duplications and speciations. Extract ortholog groups for evolutionary studies.

use_cases.title: Phylogenomic pipelines
use_cases.description: Build complete workflows from gene tree analysis to ortholog identification with taxonomy annotation.

use_cases.title: Hierarchical clustering
use_cases.description: Analyze dendrograms with cluster quality metrics including silhouette coefficient and Dunn index.

prompt_templates.title: Load tree file
prompt_templates.prompt: Load a Newick tree file named tree.nw and show its basic statistics including number of leaves, total nodes, and tree depth.

prompt_templates.title: Circular visualization
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a circular layout visualization of tree.nw. Color internal nodes by support value and export as publication-quality PDF.

prompt_templates.title: Evolutionary events
prompt_templates.prompt: Load gene_tree.nw as a PhyloTree. Set species naming function to extract species from gene names. Identify all duplication and speciation events.

prompt_templates.title: NCBI taxonomy tree
prompt_templates.prompt: Build a species tree from NCBI taxonomy for human, chimp, gorilla, and mouse. Use NCBITaxa to get taxids and annotate each node with scientific name, taxid, and taxonomic rank.

output_examples.input: Load my species_tree.nw file and show basic statistics
Create a circular visualization of my gene tree with support values
output: Style applied: Rectangular layout converted to circular
Internal nodes colored by support value (green >= 0.9, orange >= 0.7, red < 0.7)

output_examples.input: Build a taxonomy tree for human, mouse, and rat
output: Node annotations: sci_name, taxid, rank (species, genus, family, order, class, phylum, kingdom)

best_practices: Use preserve_branch_length=True when pruning trees for phylogenetic analysis
Cache NCBI taxonomy query results to avoid repeated database access
Use iterators (iter_leaves, iter_descendants) for memory-efficient processing of large trees
anti_patterns: Loading all node contents at once for very large trees without using get_cached_content
Forgetting to set species naming function before evolutionary event detection
Using raster formats (PNG) instead of vector formats (PDF/SVG) for publications

faq.question: Which Python version is required?
faq.answer: ETE Toolkit requires Python 3.7 or later. Install with: pip install ete3

faq.question: What tree formats are supported?
faq.answer: Newick, NHX, PhyloXML, and NeXML formats are supported with multiple format variants.

faq.question: How does NCBI taxonomy work?
faq.answer: NCBITaxa automatically downloads a ~300MB database on first use to ~/.etetoolkit/taxa.sqlite.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: All operations are local. ETE only accesses user-specified tree files. NCBI queries go to official NCBI servers.

faq.question: Visualization fails with Qt error
faq.answer: Install Qt dependencies: apt-get install python3-pyqt5 python3-pyqt5.qtsvg or brew install qt@5

faq.question: How does this compare to other tools?
faq.answer: ETE provides Python API access unlike command-line tools, integrates with bioinformatics workflows, and offers advanced visualization.
